title: Downing Street intervention 'prompts Boris Johnson's mother to withdraw from Parkinson's campaign'
text:
A Downing Street intervention prompted Boris Johnson's mother to withdraw her support for a public letter which was critical of Parkinson's care on the NHS, it was claimed today.

Charlotte Johnson Wahl had apparently put her name to a letter organised by the Parkinson's UK charity which had been due to be published in The Times this week.

The letter was part of the charity's Get It On Time campaign which expresses concerns about the amount of time it can take Parkinson's sufferers to receive their medication when they are in hospital.

Ms Johnson Wahl, who was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease at the age of 40, had signed the letter, according to The Guardian, but then told the charity she wanted to withdraw her support.

Parkinson's UK said in a statement that it had been told Ms Johnson Wahl, 77, was withdrawing her support 'following a conversation with Downing Street' and the letter was pulled.

The prospect of the Prime Minister's mother criticising care provision on the NHS would have been politically embarrassing for Mr Johnson.

A Number 10 source suggested Ms Johnson Wahl may not have been aware that the letter was going to be published in a national newspaper.

Charlotte Johnson Wahl, pictured alongside son Boris and daughter Rachel at an event in London in October 2014, reportedly withdrew her name from a Parkinson's UK campaign letter

A spokesperson for Parkinson’s UK said: 'With Charlotte’s permission we submitted the letter to The Times on her behalf.

'We then heard from the paper on Monday night that Charlotte was withdrawing her signature following a conversation with Downing Street.

'We later had it confirmed by Charlotte that she wished to withdraw, and The Times respected her withdrawal.'

A Downing Street source told The Guardian: 'When charities are speaking to members of the public they have a duty to be fully transparent about why they are asking for support, the campaigns they are running, and if the information shared with them is to be used in the public domain.'

Ms Johnson Wahl was recently thrust into the political spotlight after her son told Tory activists at Conservative Party conference that she had voted Leave in 2016.

The PM had been under fire from his siblings over his Brexit stance but he played his trump card in Manchester earlier this month.

He said during his set piece speech: 'And by the way for keen students of the divisions in my family you might know that I have kept the ace up my sleeve - my mother voted Leave.

The revelation delighted the crowd as it burst into cheers and applause.

It also came as a surprise to many in the main hall - especially his father Stanley Johnson who was sat alongside the PM's partner Carrie Symonds.

After the premier had made the remark, a laughing Stanley turned to Ms Symonds and said: 'I didn't know that!'
description: A Downing Street intervention prompted Boris Johnson's mother to withdraw her support for a public letter which was critical of Parkinson's care on the NHS, it was claimed today.
